thread.title: Delaware County teen convicted of role in two fatal fentanyl overdoses
thread.title_full: Delaware County teen convicted of role in two fatal fentanyl overdoses

author: The Bharat Express News
title: Delaware County teen convicted of role in two fatal fentanyl overdoses
text:
MUNCIE, Ind. – A young Delaware County man was found guilty Thursday of charges in the overdose deaths of two local teenagers.
A Delaware Circuit Court 1 jury found Jaxon W. Engle, 18, of Albany, guilty of trafficking in a controlled substance causing death; aiding, abetting, or causing the trafficking of a controlled substance resulting in death; and conspiracy to traffic in a narcotic drug.
The two most serious charges are Level 1 felonies, which carry a maximum penalty of 40 years in prison. Judge Judi Calhoun set the sentence for January 14.
In his closing address to jurors on Thursday afternoon, Chief Deputy Prosecutor Zach Craig argued there was clear evidence that Engle was a player in events that left 18-year-old Javin Nichols dead after ingesting a fentanyl pill in July 2023.
Two months later, Craig said, Engle sold one of the “blue M30” fentanyl pills to 17-year-old Kamron Lacy, who later died of an overdose.
More: Muncie man sentenced to 41 years in prison for role in fatal overdose
Craig said Engle and his accomplices “demonstrated a willingness to take advantage of those young men’s poor decisions.”
“They did it to make money,” Craig said.
Co-defendant Ricky Taylor, 25, was sentenced to 41 years in prison in July after another jury found him guilty of involvement in supplying the fentanyl that led to one of the deaths.
Dealers sue: The risk of long prison sentences due to fatal overdoses varies from country to country
Evidence presented by Craig and Deputy Prosecutor Diane Frye at Engle’s trial included dozens of texts exchanged by Engle and Taylor, described as the main supplier of the fentanyl pills.
Engle was represented by attorney Ron Smith.
In June, Engle pleaded guilty in Blackford Circuit Court to conspiracy to traffic meth.
He was accused of conspiring with his father to smuggle meth to his brother, who was being held in the Blackford County Jail at the time.
After Thursday’s verdicts were announced, Delaware County Prosecutor Eric Hoffman noted that his office had 14 convictions for trafficking resulting in death to date.
“Long gone are the days when drug dealers preyed on the weak and vulnerable,” the prosecutor said.
Douglas Walker is a news reporter at The Star Press. Contact him at 765-213-5851 or at dwalker@muncie.gannett.com .
This article originally appeared on Muncie Star Press: Jury finds Albany teen guilty of two fatal fentanyl overdoses
topics: Crime, Law and Justice->drug related crimes
